title: How many confirmed cases of COVID-19 will have been reported by the World Health Organization (WHO) for Spain as of 1 May 2020?
possible_answers: More than 100,000 but less than 140,000 cases
preds: Spain now has more than 180k confirmed cases as of today, according to Spain's Ministry of Health. https://covid19.isciii.es/

JHS counted more than 180,000 cases [1, 2]. It should be only a couple of days until the WHO counts will reach that threshold as well [3]. [1] https://gisanddata.maps.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/bda7594740fd40299423467b48e9ecf6
[2] https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/#countries
[3] https://who.sprinklr.com/region/euro/country/es
As of 2020 Apr 14th, the number of confirmed cases is 169.5K.  Increasing at an average of 4.5K per day for the past week.  We should see more than 180K by this weekend.

SKY NEWS Spain has reported a further 517 people who tested positive for covid-19 have died taking the total number of deaths in the country to 17,489 as well as 3,477 new cases of the virus taking the total to 169,496
Even if Spain starts persistently bending the curve, there is ample time for totals to exceed 180K from current totals.

Based on the latest data from the Spanish Ministry of Health and Safety ( 9 of April, 21:00 hours) the confirmed number of cases is 157,022. We can compare the situation in Spain with that of Italy and France. Given that Spain averages almost 4,000/4,500 new cases daily and some regions have not fully seen the impact of the virus it is certain that Spain will surpass more than 180,000 before the last week of April. I'd assume that before Spain gets the situation under control and infections start to decrease we could see nearly 225,000 registered cases.
Confirmed cases for COVID-19 in Spain are over 150,000 as of 10 April. On the current trajectory, foreseeable that it'd cross 180,000 cases.
With active / confirmed cases steadily increasing we're likely to see more than 180,000 cases.
Will be at 180K in less than a week.

Quadratic fit to log of daily new cases.
Yielded a median prediction of 154,957 total by May 1,
with confidence interval well within the range in question.
April 8 =140,510 cases with 22 days to go. Current rate of new cases is still over 2K per day. I hope I get a poor Brier on this one.

My previous extrapolation of around 168k cases by April 9 seemingly slighter bleak, it seems.
Still more than 99% chance of reaching more than 180k by May 1.
Depending which source you use. At 140,000 today with 22 days to go. Running 14,000 new cases a day last couple of days. You would only need to average 1800 cases a day to reach 180000.
Updating for data on 2020 Apr 7th - new case growth slowing.
Due to the spike of cases from March 25, 2020 - April 7, 2020. The total comfirmed COVID-19 cases in Spain will be over 180,000.

On April 1, I wrote "At current rate of new cases, we would hit 180,000 in about 10 days."
Things have slowed a bit. At the current rate it would still take 8 days to get to 180K. However, looking at the Italian data as a model, it seems clear that we should hit at least 160K in a week (by EOD April 12), leaving at most 20K for the remaining 16 days.  That would mean an average of less than cases 1,250 per day in that last period to remain under 180. A drop of that size seems almost impossible absent a clinical innovation introduced at scale in the very near future.

As of today, April 5, there are 130,759 cases. That means we can rule out the first two options. Looking at new cases per day, there have been about 7,500 new cases per day. That means we are also safe ruling out 100k-140k. That leaves with 140k-180k or 180k+. If the rate continues, you'll get to 130759+27*7500 = 333,259 cases. In order to get under 180k cases, the average growth rate would have to fall below 1.8k. That also seems impossible, hence we can rule out 140k-180k as well, leaving us with a 100% chance of 180k+.
The growth has been strong and 4th of April there is  124k confirmed cases.
Meanwhile, the number of infections on Thursday rose to 110,238, up from 102,136 a day earlier. 4/4

Spain Total Cases 110,238 New Cases 8,102  Total Deaths 10003 New Deaths 950 https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/coronaviruse/situation-reports/20200403-sitrep-74-covid-19-mp.pdf?sfvrsn=4e043d03_4

Spain has about 120K case as of today (numbers change from one source to the other); 

Spain’s outbreak has lagged a few days behind Italy’s but appears to be following the same trend. Daily new infections in Spain peaked at 8,271 on March 26, but appeared to have plateaued at about 8,000 every day since.
https://www.ft.com/content/c764b98d-ae03-41ac-a2ca-8309f32d5e1c
---------------------------
COMMENTS: To May 1 there are 28 days, to stay under the 180K above, they need to drop to about 1,000 from tomorrow. Very unlikely, sadly.
About 102000 April 2 with 28 days to go. It is running in excess of 5000 a day now but if it dropped to an average of 3000 for these days you would still be over 180000
By the rate of the spread of the virus
Not seeing how else it can go, especially as Spain ramps up testing for existing cases.
They're at 100,000 now.  Even if  they slow the pace,double would be optimistic
The situation shows this. Too much optimism can bring despair and unfortunately, after a certain level, it is not a load that any health system can stand.
Okay, forget it. The numbers are not slowing down.

Spain's infected cases are doubling every 7 days.  Assuming this doubling ends in 2 weeks after it started on 20 March, my logistic model shows 215k infected cases by May 1.  The 2-weeks acceleration is probably an underestimate, and therefore 100% for the last basket.

Looking at recent growth rates (9.1% on average over the recent three days) very unlikely that we will not hit 180k cases in next 3 weeks. Assuming growth rate declines by 0.5% every day we reach 180k in 10 days. Same if we assume the growth rates decline at same rate as in Italy.

Daily new cases are 8k or so at the moment, but mitigation measures take time to take effect. How many cases are reported depends on the availability of testing kits, and the Spanish testing regime has taken a hit, with over 640,000 test kits acquired from China shown to be faulty.

Current number 104k, expect around 8k new confirmed cases over the next eight days.
Almost no reason why the numbers should not go past 180k around the 2nd/3rd week of April as the new cases start to drop off.
8000 new cases per day now.  104k total now.
At current rate of new cases, we would hit 180,000 in about 10 days.

The current doubling time in Spain is 7 days for the infected cases.  However it looks like that the infected cases have reached its peak on 29 March. 
Assume that is the case, my logical model indicates 150k total cases by 1 May.  This is my forecast for now.  Will be paying close attention to the trend in the next few days.

I lowered my estimate too fast.  April 1 data has posted, and the number of cases does not appear to be flattening after all.  The Financial Times tracker says 102,136 confirmed cases in Spain.
<https://www.ft.com/coronavirus-latest>.
WHO data for April 1  has not yet posted.
New cases per week in Spain appear to be nearing a peak. <https://www.ft.com/coronavirus-latest>
The curve is bending, so maybe the worst will be avoided.
Estimate the number of Confirmed Cases by the 31st April to be between 170,000 - 175,000. I assume Spain remains in lockdown for the rest of April.
Testing capacity increasing, tests transported to other countries.
Italy may have turned the corner, will Spain be next?
cases surpassed 100000 March 31, should double by mid April

Currently at 95k cases and not slowing sharply, if slowing at all.  Slight chance that further slowing of new case rate occurs in the next few days then could stay below 180k cases.  More likely, the number of new cases per day stabilizes and declines slowly or steadily, leading to more than 180k cases by May 1.
Ran the CDC numbers through AWS Forecast and created a model that yielded only p(10) the low case number would be over 220,000 and p(90) the case number will be over 300,000
new cases are stable around 6K per day. May drop sooner than anticipated.

If my assumptions are correct, then the case numbers may just fall short of 180,000 cases. If we have a slower reduction, then we'll have more than 180,000 cases. Data [1] https://experience.arcgis.com/experience/685d0ace521648f8a5beeeee1b9125cd
Updating projection to reflect data as of 2020 Mar 30th, which shows significant decline in new case counts.

Using China and South Korea as examples for the results of confinement, testing and tracing methods in the real world, there appears to be a continuing rate of daily cases at approx 10% that of the peak days even when handled strictly. So even allowing for a rapid drop off in daily new cases, the curve still seems likely to flatten off at around 500-700 per day at two or three weeks after the peak, as a best case scenario. That being the case I still get a total of of around 170K to 210K as a ballpark.
current value of 78,797 is just over 1 doubling (2.28 x) to get to 180,000. Current doubling rate is 6 days.

I will just multiply current number by two. since it seems a peak in daily new cases has been reached. 
Possible changes in testing protocols might increase the number multiple folds as more mildly sick and assymptomatic people get tested. But April might be soon to do that.  It's also possible that shortages cause less testing.

Spain's number of cases today is 72.5K, more doubling from 5 days ago.  3 days ago, the count was 47K.  Assuming the rate of doubling slows down to 6 or 7 days, we should get 2*47K =94K in another 3-4 days, i.e. latest by 3rd April.  Let's suppose the rate of doubling slows significantly to 10 days by then.  So we'll get 2*94K = 188K by mid-April.  Given daily new cases in Spain still increasing at more than 8K, there's very slight chance that by May 1st, we'll see less than 180K cases.
My estimation is reaching 180K for Apr 19th
Effects of lockdown will ease the expotential growth of cases

Based on the trend line from https://aatishb.com/covidtrends/, it 4x every 7-8 days. 
On 1st May there will be around 2 m people infected.
March 29 = 78.8K cases per John Hopkins. Will current measures bend the curve fast enough. We will know in 2 weeks.

I am assuming their rate of growth, now at roughly 10% using trailing three days, falls 1% per day until it gets to 5% and then falls at a rate of 0.25% per day until it gets to 2% and then falls at a rate of 0.1% a day.  This gets me to 180,000 case by April 16 and 220,000 cases by the end of April.

The total cases used was from CNN: https://www.cnn.com/world/live-news/coronavirus-outbreak-03-29-20-intl-hnk/h_f1bc8a7448e0e4c77f636e2d6ae2a982
But WHO is more: https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/coronaviruse/situation-reports/20200328-sitrep-68-covid-19.pdf?sfvrsn=384bc74c_2
Statista.com about 14,000 more than that. Using Who number raises my number to more like 178,000. Chances are there will be ar least one day spiking higher. Going to put more on higest bin. Yikes!

Rate has slowed to 6% daily increase. 57,560 cases now, 32 days left to May 1. This results in 168,075. Now will the 6% hold for those 30 days? It takes 6 to 8 weeks to peak. Spain is only about 3 weeks into it. Adjusting.  https://twitter.com/justinwolfers/status/1244014016067964928?s=21
Spain will have around 80.000 cases by the end-March. It doubles its figures in 5 days. It will exceed 200.00 by end-April.

Spain already has over 70,000 cases and at the current rate of growth would reach nearly 3 million by May 1. If social distancing lowers that, the number of cases will still grow quite a bit.
since March 23  spain has  been averaging 6,000 to 700  cases a  day  and they may  just now be  peaking.   another   6 days  before dropping below 6000/ days .. thats at least another  36-40,000

March 28= 73K cases.
Spain has implemeted strong measures, hopefully, results will start to bend the curve.
About 8000 new cases yesterday. If that kept up all of April it would be well over 180,000. Watching.
A first approximation. Where are the higher buckets?

There numbers could actually be already in the 120,000 mark. They got flawed testing kits from China, which gave an only 30% chance of giving the accurate results. Once this is fixed, the numbers could skyrocket. Their number of deaths doesn't match their affected rates, its loop sided due to the poor testing regime.  https://www.politico.eu/article/spanish-government-under-fire-after-defective-testing-kits-fiasco/

Revising my forecast. It could actually even hit 180,000 next week. These lockdown measures need to have a really strong effect to halt this, to be honest with the time delay of testing and incubation this looks doubtful.  Anyway this question mainly hinges on testing: Will Spain give up testing? Or will new tests allow vast amounts of the population to obtain tests (in which case we will surely surpass 180,000). But on their current testing/infection trajectory they will easily surpass 180,000 by the given date.

Use the graph provided by the FT daily and draw your own conclusion.
https://www.ft.com/coronavirus-latest
25 days in, Spain has about 65K cases doubling at roughly 3-5 days.    Will the current lockdown continue to bend the curve toward a doubling every 7 days. Where will Spain be in 34 days?
The number of cases doubles every 3 days.

Sadly I can't see the number being less than 180,000, bearing in mind the current rate of increase is still exponential. Even allowing for a marked slow down in the rate due to the lockdown since 14th I still estimate a total over 150,000 within the next 10 days, and that leaving almost no margin for the remainder of the month.  I guessed 3 days for the lockdown to take effect, 12 days for all existing cases to show symptoms, and a big drop in the rate of transmission over the next three weeks - I still estimate over 200,000 as a best case.
They will stop the testing at one point in time.

To start I looked at the amount of total reported cases in Spain right now, which was 64,000. The incubation period of Corona is can be from 2-24 days and once symptoms begin it typically takes another 2-5 weeks for someone to either recover or die. Two weeks ago Spain only had around 5-6 thousand cases leading one to believe that the apex of the virus has yet to come. Although lockdown and isolation commenced on March 23rd the rate of cases has yet to change and with 85% of Spains population living in or near cities continuous spread is inevitable. One important counterfactual for this prediction if Spain doesn't properly develop and distribute accurate testing kits, the WHO wont be able to confirm cases of Coronavirus.
James Putnam did a deeper mathematical dive that lined-up well with my rough calculations so doing minor adjustment.
Looked at where they are on the curve upward. Not yet peaked. Have to revisit.

As of March 26, total cases are 64,000 and doubling every 4 days, which if continues would be 128,000 by April 1. Curve is flattening as evidenced by lengthening log10 increase intervals; second log 10, 7 days; third log10, 8 days; fourth log 10; in progress and currently 10 days, estimated 100,000 @ 13 days given current rate of daily new cases. Total cases are estimated to be ~10% of actual which would be 1,000,000 close to .02% of total population which is where curves in other nations tend to peak.  Social distancing is providing decrease and herd immunity especially of asymptomatic undocumented cases reduces the "fuel" of rapid expansion, reducing the likelihood of continued logarithmic expansion and achieving more than 180,000 total cases.
Extremizing based on the forecasts of the folks I'm following.

Let's consider some things first: - the lockdown in Spain is in effect since March 14
- exponential growth of cases registered ever since (currently, every ~4 days the cases double, independent of source data [1, 2])
- strong effect of lockdown in Italy still to be seen (lockdown since the 9th March) [3] => assuming Spain to be ~5 days behind,  it is likely that we see the effect of the lockdown later
=> assuming the lockdown does not reduce growth in infection numbers already at the beginning of the next week, we will likely see more ~ 100,000 cases at the end of the next week
=> assuming the lockdown reduces growth in infection numbers, we will still see an increase that will likely surpass 140,000 cases (Italy has seen increases in the margin of 5,000 patients in the last week)
=> assuming the lockdown does not reduce growth by the end of next week, more  than 180,000 cases are probable We will see how the numbers develop in the coming days. As of now, it is very likely that there will be more than 180,000 cases. [1] https://experience.arcgis.com/experience/685d0ace521648f8a5beeeee1b9125cd

See graphs of deaths for various countries in NY times web site,  Spain's death rate, I estimate currently, quadrupling in no more than 10 days.  Confirmed cases come before deaths so the total cases will be more than 4 x 39,000 = more than 160,000.  I estimate more than 350,000 cases by June 1, 2020.
Initial. Average increase and apply to how many days left? Could model countries to see what the curve is for  acceleration and deceleration. Have not fone any of the yet.
Starting with equal chances averaged against current crowd consensus. Will research further and revisit.

It’s reaching the peak plus most of the asymptomatic cases will not be reported.
If there is no recurrence of cases obviously.
I think they are starting to get a grip on the infection rate, but it will remain significant
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:CoViD-19_SP.svg Logarithmic scale indicating estimated number of cases.

Cases are currently approaching 60,000 and Spain still has not gotten through its initial two week quarantine. However, I don't think it'll go above 100,000 cases in just over a month since neither Italy nor China have that many at present. Additionally, due to recent lockdown measures, I expect the curve to begin to flatten within the next few weeks.

Spain will reach 100K on week 13-19 April. If so, we will add the people who will be infected during the next 10-15 days, so my guess is that it will be +/- 180K as of 1 May 2020.
We could see a mobilisation of Spaniards, and EU, and neighbouring countries, etc, take some measures and push the curve down. Even so, they will be in the range of 140,000 and 180,000 cases, inclusive.

180k is 3.2 times what Johns Hopkins is showing today (56,188). Spain is currently doubling every 4 days. That's 7 days to pass 180k, and 35 days until the deadline. This one seems like it's nearly a slam dunk. Containment may limit the spread before then, though. They also haven't been doing as many tests per capita as other countries, so there are probably a lot of unknown cases still out there. https://gisanddata.maps.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/bda7594740fd40299423467b48e9ecf6
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019%E2%80%9320_coronavirus_pandemic_cases/WHO_situation_reports
https://ourworldindata.org/covid-testing
Growth rate will taper out from this point, with the lockdown
Educated guess by looking at the curve
